title: 112_s922
content: The Urban Jobs Act of 2011 may be cited as the ``Urban Jobs Act of 2011''. The purpose of the Act is to address urban job issues. Congress finds that a significant number of minority youth are unemployed, individuals without a high school diploma have lower labor force participation rates, African-American and Hispanic students have lower high school graduation rates, high school dropouts cost the nation billions in lost wages, and urban high school graduation rates are below the national average. High school dropouts earn significantly less over their lifetimes compared to graduates. The curr_chunk highlights the negative impact of high school dropouts, including lower earnings, higher incarceration rates, and increased crime costs. Increasing the graduation rate could lead to significant financial savings and reduce crime rates. The purpose of the Act is to support nonprofit organizations in preventing disproportionate youth incarceration and preparing them for successful entry into society. The Act aims to provide resources for nonprofit organizations to prevent disproportionate youth incarceration and prepare them for employment or education leading to economic self-sufficiency. SEC. 3. URBAN JOBS PROGRAMS. Amends the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 to include a new section on Urban Jobs Programs. The section aims to provide competitive grants for urban youth aged 18-24, focusing on those out of school or involved in the criminal justice system. It aims to establish a feeder system into employment or education leading to employment, offer holistic preparation services, and reduce disproportionate youth incarceration in urban communities. Definitions include 'community-based affiliate' as a local organization affiliated with a national intermediary. The section defines terms like 'community-based affiliate' as a local organization affiliated with a national intermediary and 'eligible youth' as individuals aged 18-24 not in school or involved in the criminal justice system. The national intermediary must have an affiliate network in at least 50 urban communities and operate in 25 states for over 20 years. The Urban Jobs Program provides workforce investment activities to eligible youth in urban communities, aiming to reduce recidivism and offer pathways to employment or education. Grants are given to national intermediaries to operate these programs, which must have a network in 50 urban communities and have been active in 25 states for over 20 years. The Urban Jobs Program offers services to eligible youth in urban communities to provide a pathway to employment or education leading to employment. National intermediaries must submit an application with specified grant amount and usage details to receive funding for the program. The national intermediary for the Urban Jobs Program must describe how they will achieve goals such as increased long-term employment, reduced recidivism, improved education attainment, literacy, and industry certifications. They must also outline the program's underlying supports, including engaged community partners. The national intermediary for the Urban Jobs Program must describe underlying supports for the program, including engaged community partners, staff expertise in youth development, and understanding of youth characteristics. The program should enable participants to create caring relationships, set goals for employment, education attainment, and higher education completion. The curr_chunk describes various aspects of attainment and development for program participants, including employment, education, community service, workplace skills, and responsibility for their future. The curr_chunk outlines the development goals for program participants, including workplace skills, responsibility for their future, goal-setting strategies, risk reduction, improved educational and employment outcomes, and reduced recidivism through activities in the Urban Jobs Program leading to industry-recognized certificates. The Urban Jobs Program aims to provide activities leading to industry-recognized certificates. Eligible activities include case management and educational services like skill assessment and career pathway connections. The Urban Jobs Program offers services for high school diploma equivalency, career pathways, employment readiness, support services, and job training. Only 2 percent of funds can be used for other purposes. The Urban Jobs Program provides housing assistance, basic living skills, transportation, child care, clothing, and other necessary support services. The Secretary of Labor must submit progress reports to relevant committees, and the program is not subject to evaluations required under section 172. The Secretary of Labor is responsible for establishing the National Jobs Council Advisory Committee. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee, established by the Secretary of Labor, consists of 11 members from the private sector, high-growth industries, national intermediaries, and the Department of Labor. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee, established by the Secretary of Labor, consists of 11 members from high-growth industries, national intermediaries, and the Department of Labor. Members are appointed for the life of the Committee and are responsible for analyzing the program, preparing recommendations for the Secretary, and generating reports. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee, established by the Secretary of Labor, consists of 11 members responsible for analyzing the program, preparing recommendations, and generating reports. Members do not receive compensation but are allowed travel expenses for their services. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee, established by the Secretary of Labor, may accept voluntary and uncompensated services from its members. Federal government employees can be detailed to the Committee without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status. The Committee is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Congress recommends that community-based affiliates establish local jobs council advisory committees, with at least one-third of members being local community representatives. The curr_chunk discusses the establishment of a local jobs council advisory committee to support and guide the implementation of a program, with at least one-third of members being employers in high-impact industries. Additionally, it outlines funding amounts for urban jobs programs over the next few fiscal years. Establishment of a local jobs council advisory committee to support urban jobs programs, with funding amounts outlined for the next few fiscal years.
